title: UK doctor gives details of Jayalalithaa's treatment - The Hindu
text:
February 06, 2017 14:34 IST Updated: February 06, 2017 14:47 IST more-in Jayalalithaa 
Dr. Richard Beale who had looked after the health of late Chief Minister Jayalalithaa on Monday addressed a press conference in Chennai. He was accompanied by Dr. Balaji from the State government and Dr. Babu Abraham, Critical Care Consultant. 
Dr. Abraham further stated "Sepsis can come on extremely quickly. People become unwell in a matter of hours/days." 
Dr Babu "once she was in a ventilator we had to give her sleeping medicines and wasn't able to communicate. But when she was awake, she would communicate with signs." 
"Usually in a VIP death, body will be in state, with our climatic conditions too, it's possible to contaminate the body. So we embalmed her, just as we did for MGR." 
Sudha seshaiyyan, Director of anatomy, who did the embalming. Embalming was done at midnight 12-20 it started, went on for 15 minutes. 
Dr. Beale said "There was no amputation and no transplantation either." 
Dr. Richard Beale said "As far as I'm aware she became short of breath quite rapidly. To a question, Dr. Beale said "She could have come earlier." 
"Continued with sign language and lip reading once she got a trachaeostomy." 
"Also attached to the heart, contributiing to endocarditis." 
"Sepsis can come on quickly and have severe consequences." 
"She also had co morbidities - uncontrolled diabetes." 
"When she came into hospital she was treated with non invasive ventilation - mask to the face. She got better somewhat. "

"Then as her sepsis got worse progressively she had to go on a ventilator." 
At that time chest and urine were suspected. 
Dr. Babu Abraham gave a timeline on Jayalalithaa's health condition. Dr. Abraham said "On September 22, Jayalalithaa was admitted at 10.30 p.m. and immediately given critical and supportive care." 
Dr. Abraham said "Ms. Jayalalithaa was short of breath at home and the ambulance was called and came to Apollo Hospitals." 
He further said "At that time diagnosis was respiratory failure due to infection."
